monogr.title: Die alten Übersetzungen des Neuen Testaments, die Kirchenväterzitate und Lektionare: Der gegenwartige Stand ihrer Erforschung und ihre Bedeutung für die griechische Textgeschichte

biblStruct.note: The chapter opens with some remarks on recent work on Ephrem's Diatessaron commentary and on the various views about the genesis of the Peshitta; the bulk of the chapter, however, is devoted to the relationship between the Old Syriac and the Diatessaron, and here Black argues that the Diatessaron precedes, and has influenced, the Old Syriac. Although some of the arguments used seem to be in danger of being circular, I would certainly agree with this general conclusion, and simply add that, where OT quotations are preserved in the Syriac Diatessaron tradition (which is lamentably rare), these tend to be entirely adapted to the Peshitta OT, whereas in C and S some modification is usually made towards the Greek form of the quotation in the NT, and in the Peshitta NT the Greek is followed closely: such a situation must mean that the Diatessaron preceeds the Old Syriac, and not vice versa. Black also discusses the date of the Old Syriac Gospels (a comparatively late one is preferred), and the lost Old Syriac to the Acts and Epistles. The other Syriac versions are treated much more briefly (pp. 139-42), and the three paragraphs on the 'Palestinian Syriac' curiously ignore Perrot's important publication of the Khirbet Mird Acts fragment (Revue Biblique, 1963). [S. Brock, JTS]
